title: This Braintree mom is running Boston for Mass. Eye and Ear
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Katie Nicoloro, 40, from Braintree will run her first Boston Marathon in 2026.
Nicoloro aims to inspire her children by showing them that difficult goals can be achieved.
She is participating in the marathon to support Mass. Eye and Ear hospital.

title: Group of juveniles kick man into moving train at Back Bay Station
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: A 27-year-old man was kicked into a moving Orange Line train at Back Bay Station, suffering a forehead injury.
The incident occurred after a dispute with juveniles at approximately 6:46 p.m., according to MBTA Transit Police.
The suspects fled the scene, and police are investigating with no arrests made by Wednesday morning.

title: Framingham Baking Co. to close after 109 years in business
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Framingham Baking Co., a staple since 1917, will close on March 29, ending 109 years of family operation.
The bakery is known for its sheet pizzas with over two dozen flavors, along with bread, rolls, and desserts.
The closure announcement prompted emotional customer reactions, with many urging to preserve the bakery's recipes.

title: AG Campbell files brief to block termination of protected status for Haitian immigrants
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: AG Andrea Campbell filed a brief to maintain the block on ending Haitian Temporary Protected Status (TPS).
Haitians contribute $3.4 billion annually to the U.S. economy, with Massachusetts hosting a sizable Haitian population.
The brief argues ending TPS would destabilize families, affect public health, and damage healthcare workforce in the U.S.

title: City councilor asks police to investigate group of bikers seen in Chinatown
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: City Councilor Ed Flynn asked police to investigate bikers seen in Chinatown and Leather District on Tuesday.
Flynn highlighted concerns about pedestrian safety and requested stricter enforcement of traffic laws for motorized vehicles.
A BPD spokesperson noted the group's presence near Boston Common but no police report was found by Wednesday.

title: Ernie Adams named interim football coach at Phillips Andover
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Ernie Adams named interim varsity football coach at Phillips Andover for the 2026 season, replacing Trey Brown.
Adams, a former Patriots research director, was a classmate of Bill Belichick at Phillips Andover in the 1970s.
Adams, 72, will lead the team after spending time there part-time post-retirement; he assumes his first head coach role.

title: 2 ‘storybook escapes’ for 2026 are in New England, according to HomeToGo
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Woodstock, Vermont, and Bar Harbor, Maine were named top storybook escapes for 2026 by HomeToGo.
Woodstock ranked 11th, with a median nightly cost of $153 and a 105% increase in search trends.
Bar Harbor ranked 14th, featuring charming B&Bs, with a median nightly price of $174 and a 39% search trend rise.

title: Patriots reportedly set to name Zak Kuhr as defensive coordinator
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Zak Kuhr is set to be officially named the New England Patriots' defensive coordinator for the 2026 season.
Kuhr, 37, served as interim defensive coordinator in 2025 during Terrell Williams' cancer leave, leading a top-performing defense.
Terrell Williams will move to a senior coaching role, and Vinny DePalma will become the Patriots' inside linebackers coach.

title: This music teacher is running the Boston Marathon for Parkinson’s research
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Owen Hughes Jr., a music teacher from Westchester, NY, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon.
Hughes is running to raise funds for The Michael J. Fox Foundation in honor of his father with Parkinson's.
This will be Hughes' ninth marathon since he started running in 2022, inspired by personal and family motivations.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 18)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: 840 Hancock St. in Abington, a 1,872 sq ft Colonial built in 1984, sold for $705,000.
405 Great Elm Way #405 in Acton, a 1,700 sq ft townhouse built in 1972, sold for $502,500.
32 W Cedar St. in Boston, a 4,013 sq ft row-middle built in 1820, sold for $4,800,000.
